filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of the electronic editions of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell copies K, L, and M. The Archive is also publishing the collection list for the Victoria University Library in Toronto and Alexander Gourlay's revised Glossary of Terms, Names, and Concepts in Blake.
Blake etched twenty-seven plates for Marriage in relief in 1790. Copy K is an early printing of plates 21-24, and copies L and M are early printings of plates 25-27, "A Song of Liberty." Copy K is in the Fitzwilliam Museum, copy L is in the Essick Collection, and copy M, formerly in the Bentley Collection, is in the Victoria University Library. Only nine complete copies of the Marriage are known to exist; copies K, L, and M, apparently printed as autonomous pamphlets, join six complete copies previously published in the Archive (and now republished with corrected transcriptions).
The four plates of copy K were printed in black ink on both sides of a single sheet of wove paper, folded down the middle after printing to form two leaves. Plate 21 is in its first state and the vignette on plate 24 is missing, probably masked during printing but possibly not yet executed. In copies L and M, plate 25 is in its first state, and thus these copies were also printed very early in the production process; in copy M, the eight lines of the "Chorus" on plate 27 were masked during printing. The plates were printed on single sheets folded down the middle to form pamphlets of two leaves. Copy L was printed in brownish-black on laid paper and copy M was printed in grayish-black on wove paper.
Like all the illuminated books in the Archive, the text and images of Marriage copies K, L, and M are fully searchable and are supported by our Inote and ImageSizer applications. With the Archive's Compare feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across the different copies of this or any of the other illuminated books. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to all copies of Marriage in the Archive.
With the publication of Marriage copies K, L, and M, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of sixty-five copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, sketches, and water color drawings, including Blake's illustrations to Thomas Gray's Poems, water color and engraved illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy, the large color printed drawings of 1795 and c. 1805, the Linnell and Butts sets of the Book of Job water colors and the sketchbook containing drawings for the engraved illustrations to the Book of Job, the water color illustrations to Robert Blair's The Grave, and the water color illustrations to John Milton's Paradise Regained, L'Allegro, and Il Penseroso, as well as the Butts and Thomas sets of illustrations to Milton's Comus, Nativity ode, and Paradise Lost.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objnote.p: The plate is in the first state, before the deletion from the copperplate of the final 5 words in line 13.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Looped vines grow from the descenders of "Song" and "Liberty" in the plate's opening inscription. The first of these vegetative motifs joins with the "E" of "Eternal" in line 2. To the right of "A Song of Liberty," a stylized leaf appears. Three grape leaves on a vine follow "Earth" in line 3. Two lines down, a long, thin branch with abundant tiny leaves stretches to the right margin. More grape leaves—these attached to a vine with a two-looped tendril—ornament the space next to "Rome" in line 10. Two soaring birds fly left of the vine. A flame-like leaf, for which a gowned female reaches, extends from the "g" of "howling" in line 15. More flame-like vegetation appears behind the figure, as well as near the right margin of line 18. A flower- or leaf-bearing vine grows from the descender of "deep" in line 21. Adjacent to it are three birds—the two outside ones are small and nondescript—followed by some seemingly wind-blown vegetation—or perhaps the feathery objects represent the "jealous wings [that] wav'd / over the deep," mentioned in lines 20 and 21. In the bottom left corner of the plate, the ubiquitous grapevine and leaf combination continues, attached to the "y" of "jealousy." The "g's" of "among" and "flaming" in line 24 also sport flourishes, the former vegetative, the latter a flame-like(?) tassel, possibly representing the "flaming hair" named in the text. Various other small-scale vegetative designs adorn the plate, e.g., the leaf-bearing stem preceding verse 7 in line 14, and the leafy attachment to the "A" in the opening inscription.

component.illusobjdesc: Numerous vines and grape leaves ornament the plate: in the opening inscription, a vine connects the "g" of "Song" with the "E" of "Eternal" in line 2, and a five-looped vine, suggestive of a spiral, extends from the "y" of "Liberty." Three grape leaves on a vine follow "Earth" in line 3. Further down, right of line 10, four grape leaves grow from a long tendril that stretches to the right margin. A flower- or leaf-bearing vine is attached to the "p" of "deep" in line 21. At the bottom left corner of the plate, the vine and grape leaf emblem extends from the "y" of "jealousy."

Various other vegetative motifs adorn the plate: to the right of the opening inscription, "A Song of Liberty," a stylized leaf appears. Attached to the "t" of "faint" in line 5, a long, thin branch with abundant tiny leaves stretches to the right margin. A leaf-bearing stem grows from the "g" of "among" in line 24. Smaller-scale motifs appear passim, e.g., the leafy flourishes of "wav'd" at the end of line 20 and of "A" in line 1, and the detached leaves preceding verse 7 in line 14.
Five birds grace the plate: two soar to the right of "Rome" in line 10, and three—the outside ones small and nondescript—fly above "burned aloft" in line 22.

A flame-like leaf, for which a gowned female reaches, extends from the "g" of "howling" in line 15. More flame- or wing-like vegetation appears behind the figure, as well as near the right margin of line 18. The three soaring birds of line 21 are followed by some seemingly wind-blown leaves, or perhaps the feathery fragments represent the "jealous wings [that] wav'd/over the deep," mentioned in lines 20 and 21.
Following "howling" in line 15, a hovering female faces left. She wears a gown and extends one arm, touching the flame-like leaf in front of her. Her body is horizontal.
At the bottom of the plate, a flame-like(?) tassel grows from the "g" of "flaming" in line 24. The motif may visually represent the "flaming hair" of the text.

lg.l: 1. The Eternal Female groand! it was
heard over all the Earth:
2. Albions coast is sick silent; the A-
-merican meadows faint!
3 Shadows of Prophecy shiver along by
the lakes and the rivers and mutter across
the ocean, France rend down thy dungeon;
4. Golden Spain burst the barriers of old
Rome;
5. Cast thy keys O Rome into the deep
down falling, even to eternity down falling,
6. And weep and bow thy reverend locks!
7. In her trembling hands she took the
new born terror howling:
8. On those infinite mountains of light
now barr'd out by the atlantic sea, the new
born fire stood before the starry king!
9. Flag'd with grey brow'd snows and thun-
-derous visages the jealous wings wav'd
over the deep.
10. The speary hand burned aloft, unbuck-
-led was the shield, forth went the hand
of jealousy among the flaming hair. and

illustration.illusobjdesc: Following "night" in line 2, a stag leaps right. Just beyond it, a leafless tree arches to the ground. An upside-down figure personifies the "falling" fire of line 3. Next to it are some hatched lines wherein are discernible two horses running left in other copies, but here the cluster of lines (if representational at all) suggests clouds. Two figures, many of the details of their gestures and positions indistinct, follow "forehead" in line 8. They sit facing each other, the second gowned or otherwise draped. To the right of these figures, another tree(?) arches right, its leafless branch seemingly pointing toward a serpentine vine that connects with the "h" of "shot" at the end of line 9. Further down, a snake (or simply a line?) extends from "away" in line 12 to the right margin. A relatively large-scale interlinear branch and leaf combination ornaments the space beside "rocks" in line 18. Hovering above "then" in line 21, a somewhat shadowy figure faces right, its body horizontal. It extends one arm forward, touching the hand of a sitting figure. A group of five figures, possibly signifying the "gloomy king" and his retinue of lines 15-17, appears after "king" in line 23: the first figure stands facing right; the second sits cross-legged(?) on the ground. They are followed by two figures who stand with arms extended, hailing the final figure, perhaps the king. He walks toward them with arms outstretched. Above "his" at the end of line 24 is a large leaf. Various other vegetative motifs adorn the plate, e.g., the looped vines growing from the ascenders of "London" and "thunder" in lines 4 and 24; the leaf extending from the "h" of "then" in line 21; and the banner waving from the "b" of "born" in line 1.

component.illusobjdesc: Following "night" in line 2, a stag—its horns discernible—leaps right.
Just beyond the stag following "night" in line 2, a tree arches right, its leafless branches nearly touching the ground.

To the right of the leafless tree below line 1, an upside-down figure personifies the "falling" fire of line 3. The figure is seen from behind and faces down. Its arms are raised at 135 degrees. Fire or flame-like drapery trails behind the figure's legs.
Fire or flame-like drapery trails behind the falling figure's legs.

Discernible in the hatching near the right margin at the ends of lines 2 and 3 are two horses leaping or running right in other copies, but here the cluster of lines (if representational at all) suggests clouds.

A sketchy scene follows the word "forehead" in line 8: the first of two figures sits facing right, its arms slightly extended. The figure appears engrossed in some indeterminable activity; its lower body is not shown, as though buried in the earth.
Following the word "forehead" in line 8, the second of two figures sits facing left, its legs extended. The figure is robed or wrapped in a blanket.

An ambiguous motif appears below "winged" in line 7 and to the right of a seated pair of figures. It may be a tree or stump, not unlike the larger tree of line 2, with a leafless branch extending toward or pointing at a serpentine vine.
At the end of line 8 is a tree or stump whose leafless branch seems to point toward a serpentine vine near the right margin of the plate.
Following "away" in line 12, a snake (or simply a line?) extends to the right margin.
A leaf-bearing stem or branch follows "rocks" in line 18 and stretches to the right margin of the plate.
Hovering above "then" in line 21, a shadowy figure faces right, its body horizontal. It extends one arm forward, touching the hand of a seated figure.
Following "then" in line 21, a figure sits facing forward, but with its head possibly turned to the left. It has one arm raised horizontally and touches the hand of the hovering figure above left.
Toward the bottom of the plate, a group of figures—five in all—appears above verse 18 of the "Song." They may illustrate the "gloomy king" (far right) and his retinue, described in lines 14-23.

Following "king" in line 23 is a group of five figures, perhaps the monarch and his retinue, described in lines 14-23. The first pair possibly represents two of the king's "councellors," "warriors," or "veterans," cited in lines 14-15. One of the figures stands facing right, arms slightly extended. The second sits cross-legged(?) on the ground. The first figure is gowned.

The second pair of figures following "king" in line 23 possibly represents two of the king's "councellors," "warriors," or "veterans," cited in lines 14-15. They stand facing right. The figure on the right in this pair extends one arm forward. Its companion seems to hold an object; its arms may also be outstretched. Both figures are gowned.

The last figure of line 23 may illustrate the "gloomy king" of the text. He appears to wear a gown that trails behind him; he walks leftward toward his "counsellors" and "warriors." The king's arms are extended horizontally.
A large leaf appears above "his" at the end of line 24.

Various vegetative motifs adorn the plate, e.g., the looped vines growing from the ascenders of "London" and "thunder" in lines 4 and 24; the leaf extending from the "h" of "then" in line 21; and the banner waving from the "b" of "born" in line 1.

lg.l: hurl'd the new born wonder thro' the starry
night.
11. The fire, the fire, is falling!
12. Look up! look up! O citizen of London
enlarge thy countenance; O Jew, leave coun
ting gold! return to thy oil and wine; O
African! black African! (go. winged thought
widen his forehead.)
13. The fiery limbs, the flaming hair, shot
like the sinking sun into the western sea.
14. Wak'd from his eternal sleep, the hoary
element roaring fled away;
15. Down rushd beating his wings in vain
the jealous king; his grey brow'd councel-
-lors, thunderous warriors, curl'd veterans,
among helms, and shields, and chariots
horses, elephants: banners, castles, slings
and rocks,
16. Falling, rushing, ruining! buried in
the ruins, on Urthona's dens.
17. All night beneath the ruins, then
their sullen flames faded emerge round
the gloomy king,
18. With thunder and fire: leading his
starry hosts thro' the waste wilderness

objnote.p: "Chorus" (line 13) and lines 14-21 were masked during printing and do not appear in this copy.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Following "dismay" in line 3, a figure holds a staff—or a scepter if one takes him for the "starry" and "gloomy" king of this "Song of Liberty." He kneels on one leg and points(?) toward another figure with his left arm, raised horizontally. Running amidst wispy clouds, this second figure may represent the "son of fire in his eastern / cloud," who is named in lines 4 and 5 and in whose direction the king of the text casts his eyes. Three lines down, two horses, one of which is mounted, gallop leftward in the direction of another horse(?)—this one recumbent—and an indistinct form, both of which rest on some grassy tableland. The horse motif reappears below the text, where two horses. The horse on the left gallops or leaps toward the text. Its companion rears up on hind legs, arching its head and back. A small bird soars to the left of the horse on the right. Vines follow the last line of text. Various other vegetative motifs adorn the plate, e.g., the looped vine growing from the "t" of "breast" in lines 6 and a small leaf-bearing branch below "Spurning" in line 7.

component.illusobjdesc: Following "dismay" in line 3, a figure holds a staff—or a scepter if one takes him for the king of the "Song" who, in lines 2-4, casts "his beamy eyelids" in the direction of the "son of fire," visually depicted near the right margin. The king(?) kneels on one leg and points or otherwise gestures toward this second figure.

Following "dismay" in line 3, a figure kneels on one leg, holding a staff or scepter. To his right is another figure. Leaping or running amidst wispy clouds, this second figure may represent the "son of fire in his eastern / cloud," who is named in lines 4 and 5. His arms are raised nearly horizontally.

The second figure following "dismay" in line 3 is surrounded by wispy, curving lines, suggestive of clouds; the visual details reinforce the epithet of lines 4 and 5: "the son of fire in his eastern / cloud."
Following "breast" in line 6, a horse and an indistinct form—perhaps vegetation—lie resting on a bit of grassy tableland. The horse faces right.
Two horses—the first of which carries a rider—gallop leftward in the direction of the recumbent horse following "breast" in line 6.
A rider sits astride the first horse following "breast" in line 6.
Two clumps of indeterminate vegetation, possibly tall grasses, grow between the end of line 6 and the recumbent horse.
Two horses appear below the text. The horse on the left gallops or leaps toward the right.
Two horses appear below the text. The horse on the right rears up on its hind legs, bending its head back. It faces left and up.
Serpentine vines follow the last line of text.
A small bird flies to the left of the horse on the right.

Various vegetative motifs adorn the plate, e.g., the looped vine growing from the "t" of "breast" in lines 6, a small leaf-bearing branch below "Spurning" in line 7, the plant-like or vine-like form following line 7, and the single detached leaf above "curses" in line 8.

lg.l: he promulgates his ten commands,
glancing his beamy eyelids over the
deep in dark dismay,
19. Where the son of fire in his eastern
cloud, while the morning plumes her gol-
-den breast.
20. Spurning the clouds written with
curses. stamps the stony law to dust,
loosing the eternal horses from the dens
of night, crying Empire is no more!
and now the lion & wolf shall
cease.
